Award.AwardTitle: Enhancing the Life Cycle of Plastic Pipes Through Nano-reinforcement

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project brings together research on advanced (nano) and recycled materials suitable for plastic pipe infrastructure, life cycle costing, and a practical tool targeted to pipe manufacturers and public utility end-users. Experimental testing methods combined with multi-scale modeling will be used to characterize the material response of nanoclay reinforced plastic pipe when subjected to stress conditions expected during the service life of infrastructure pipe; and to determine nanoclay and recycled plastic compositions that meet service life standards for pressure and non-pressure conditions. Multiscale models will be developed based on polymer molecular structures to capture the cracking behavior and to predict the lifetime of pipe made from appropriate mixes of pristine and nanoclay reinforced recycled plastic.

Research results from material testing, to multi-scale model, to life cycle model, will formulate the empirical basis for a practical and publicly available pipe cost tool directed at pipe manufacturers to guide the selection of material in designing nanocomposite plastic pipe. Successful completion of this project will have a broad impact on engineering materials and will also strengthen graduate and undergraduate education in the awareness of new construction materials and their advantages and limitations regarding performance and associated costs. Multiple case study projects with real-world infrastructure application will be created based on the proposed research to serve as platforms for graduate students to provide mentoring to undergraduate students. Students will learn both the engineering fundamentals and environmental and cost aspects of emerging construction materials and the importance of implementing engineering research into practice. The recycling of plastics along will the science associated with the process will ground an environmentally themed K-12 education program.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to evaluate whether using nanoclay material improves the service life of plastic pipe made from a mixture of pristine (P) and recycled (R) high density polyethylene (HDPE) as a means of improving its environmental and economic sustainability. The project investigated material properties and parameters that affect environmental and economic sustainability when using nanoclay in mixed recycled/pristine polymer composites.

HDPE polymer is used in civil and geotechnical pipe infrastructure and comprises an important long-lived asset for the conveyance of nearly every fluid utility used by society including, water, wastewater, and liquid and gaseous energy distribution. This project addressed the question of whether using a nanoclay material with both recycled and pristine HDPE (nanoclay composite), enhanced or merely maintained the service life of plastic pipe relative to pristine HDPE pipe, which is widely used today in corrugated highway drainage pipe. To answer this question, the project team investigated; 1) the failure mechanisms of HDPE material specimens made from recycled and pristine polymer through mechanical testing and numerical simulation (finite element modeling) of crack growth and fracture morphology; 2) the failure mechanisms of nanoclay composites made with 2-, 4- and 6-wt% nanoclay and recycled and pristine blends of HDPE using mechanical tests and fracture morphology; 3) the failure time, mode, and properties of pristine/recycled HDPE nanoclay composites; and 4) the life cycle greenhouse gas emissions, non-renewable energy, and life cycle cost (LCC) of pristine/recycled HDPE nanoclay composites used for highway drainage pipe. 

Research findings showed that:

1) Blending brittle recycled material with ductile pristine HDPE decreased the fracture toughness and the crack growth resistance;

2) Adding 6-wt% nanoclay to pristine HDPE and 2-wt% nanoclay to recycled blends resulted in a transition from ductile to brittle failure. Micrographs (Image 1) depict the fracture surfaces of the material containing 75-wt% of recycled HDPE (P25R75) with nanoclay composites.

3) The long-term stress cracking behavior of pristine/recycled HDPE and pristine/recycled HDPE nanocomposites were expressed via the logarithmic stress intensity factor K and the logarithmic failure time:

a) Failure behavior in recycled/pristine HDPE blends showed that increases in recycled HDPE decreased failure time in pristine/recycled HDPE blends: increasing the recycled content from 25% to 50% decreased the failure time by 69% under the same stress intensity (K). Further increases in recycled content to 75% reduced the failure time by 82% compared to recycled content of 25%;

b) Failure behavior in recycle/pristine HDPE nanoclay composites exhibited a bilnear stress cracking behavior (Image 2) compared to recycle-blends without nanoclay (Image 3), suggesting that the fracture mechanism in the polymer composite also depends on the loading condition: creep failure at high stress intensity (K) whereas slow crack growth (SCG) failure at low stress intensity (K).

c) Failure behavior in recycle/pristine HDPE nanoclay composites showed that the addition of nanoclay increased the failure time over the corresponding polymer materials. For P75R25 (Image 2a) and P50R50 (Image 2b), 2-wt% of nanoclay drastically increased the failure time by 2.8 and 2.4 times in the SCG failure region, respectively.

4) Life cycle assessment findings for 100% pristine HDPE and 50%/50% pristine and recycle (P50R50) nanocomposite showed that greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions for the nanoclay pristine/recycled HDPE pipe are approximately 36% lower than the GHG emissions for pristine HDPE, and 15% lower than the GHG emissions for pristine/recycled HDPE (Image 4); the production of nanoclay does not introduce a significant environmental ...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project was to evaluate whether using nanoclay material improves the service life of plastic pipe made from a mixture of pristine (P) and recycled (R) high density polyethylene (HDPE) as a means of improving its environmental and economic sustainability. The project investigated material properties and parameters that affect environmental and economic sustainability when using nanoclay in mixed recycled/pristine polymer composites. HDPE polymer is used in civil and geotechnical pipe infrastructure and comprises an important long-lived asset for the conveyance of nearly every fluid utility used by society including, water, wastewater, and liquid and gaseous energy distribution. This project addressed the question of whether using a nanoclay material with both recycled and pristine HDPE (nanoclay composite), enhanced or merely maintained the service life of plastic pipe relative to pristine HDPE pipe, which is widely used today in corrugated highway drainage pipe. To answer this question, the project team investigated; 1) the failure mechanisms of HDPE material specimens made from recycled and pristine polymer through mechanical testing and numerical simulation (finite element modeling) of crack growth and fracture morphology; 2) the failure mechanisms of nanoclay composites made with 2-, 4- and 6-wt% nanoclay and recycled and pristine blends of HDPE using mechanical tests and fracture morphology; 3) the failure time, mode, and properties of pristine/recycled HDPE nanoclay composites; and 4) the life cycle greenhouse gas emissions, non-renewable energy, and life cycle cost (LCC) of pristine/recycled HDPE nanoclay composites used for highway drainage pipe. Research findings showed that: 1) Blending brittle recycled material with ductile pristine HDPE decreased the fracture toughness and the crack growth resistance; 2) Adding 6-wt% nanoclay to pristine HDPE and 2-wt% nanoclay to recycled blends resulted in a transition from ductile to brittle failure. Micrographs (Image 1) depict the fracture surfaces of the material containing 75-wt% of recycled HDPE (P25R75) with nanoclay composites. 3) The long-term stress cracking behavior of pristine/recycled HDPE and pristine/recycled HDPE nanocomposites were expressed via the logarithmic stress intensity factor K and the logarithmic failure time: a) Failure behavior in recycled/pristine HDPE blends showed that increases in recycled HDPE decreased failure time in pristine/recycled HDPE blends: increasing the recycled content from 25% to 50% decreased the failure time by 69% under the same stress intensity (K). Further increases in recycled content to 75% reduced the failure time by 82% compared to recycled content of 25%; b) Failure behavior in recycle/pristine HDPE nanoclay composites exhibited a bilnear stress cracking behavior (Image 2) compared to recycle-blends without nanoclay (Image 3), suggesting that the fracture mechanism in the polymer composite also depends on the loading condition: creep failure at high stress intensity (K) whereas slow crack growth (SCG) failure at low stress intensity (K). c) Failure behavior in recycle/pristine HDPE nanoclay composites showed that the addition of nanoclay increased the failure time over the corresponding polymer materials. For P75R25 (Image 2a) and P50R50 (Image 2b), 2-wt% of nanoclay drastically increased the failure time by 2.8 and 2.4 times in the SCG failure region, respectively. 4) Life cycle assessment findings for 100% pristine HDPE and 50%/50% pristine and recycle (P50R50) nanocomposite showed that greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions for the nanoclay pristine/recycled HDPE pipe are approximately 36% lower than the GHG emissions for pristine HDPE, and 15% lower than the GHG emissions for pristine/recycled HDPE (Image 4); the production of nanoclay does not introduce a significant environmental burden on the polymer nanocomposite.
